Literature Review: The COVID-19 pandemic, caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, has led to unprecedented global health challenges. A critical aspect of the immune response to SARS-CoV-2 involves T cells, which play a pivotal role in controlling viral infections. This literature review focuses on the current understanding of T cell responses to SARS-CoV-2, including the impact of infection and vaccination, the role of T cells in disease severity, and the durability and variant resilience of T cell memory. Recent studies have demonstrated that both SARS-CoV-2 infection and vaccination induce robust CD4 and CD8 T cell responses. These responses are characterized by their polyfunctionality and the recognition of multiple epitopes across the viral genome. Early and robust T cell responses have been associated with milder COVID-19 outcomes, suggesting that T cells contribute significantly to controlling the severity of the disease. This is supported by animal model data, which indicate that while antibodies are crucial for preventing infection, T cells are essential for reducing disease severity and controlling viral replication. The durability of T cell memory following SARS-CoV-2 vaccination has been a subject of extensive research. Studies have shown that T cell memory persists for at least six months post-vaccination, providing a sustained immune defense against the virus. This is particularly important in the context of emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants, which have shown the ability to evade neutralizing antibody responses. However, most CD4 and CD8 T cell responses remain preserved against these variants, highlighting the resilience of T cell immunity. Despite the significant progress made in understanding T cell responses to SARS-CoV-2, several knowledge gaps remain. These include the long-term durability of T cell memory beyond six months, the impact of T cell responses on transmission dynamics, and the potential for T cell-based vaccines to provide broad protection against emerging variants. Addressing these gaps will be crucial for developing more effective strategies to combat COVID-19 and future pandemics. In conclusion, T cells play a critical role in the immune response to SARS-CoV-2, contributing to disease control and severity reduction. The preservation of T cell responses against emerging variants underscores the importance of T cell immunity in the ongoing fight against COVID-19. Continued research into T cell responses will be essential for enhancing our understanding of SARS-CoV-2 immunity and informing the development of next-generation vaccines.
